Using the Crisp Template

Zhenguo Zhang

2025-11-02

Source: vignettes/crisp.Rmd
crisp.Rmd

Introduction

The crisp template is a clean, modern resume template with customizable typography and layout options. It provides a clean, professional layout with tighter margins and spacing for creating concise resumes. This vignette demonstrates how to use the template with various entry types.

Template Features

  • Monochrome output (no colors, except for the section titles)
  • Customize the color of first 3 characters in section title with ‘headcolor’
  • Compact layout with tighter margins
  • Flexible entry types (detailed, brief, honors, skills)
  • Customizable spacing after section title using ‘spacing_after_section_title’
  • Header with inline contact information
  • Choose from the font family: Roboto, Times New Roman
  • All other header options in awesomecv, such as address, email, etc.

Basic Setup

First, load the required packages:

library(vitae)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'vitae'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter
library(tibble)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

Creating a Resume

Document Header

Create your resume by setting up an R Markdown document with the following YAML header:

---
title: "Your Name"
author: Your Name
date: "2025-11-02"
output: vitae::crisp
position: "Data Scientist"
address: "123 Main Street, City, Country"
phone: "+1 234 567 8900"
email: "email@example.com"
github: "fortune9"
linkedin: "username"
headcolor: "0000FF"      # Blue color for the 3 characters in section title
spacing_after_section_title: "-1mm"  # Compress section spacing
---

Using Different Entry Types

Detailed Entries

Use detailed_entries() for experience sections like work history or education:

tribble(
  ~title, ~unit, ~loc, ~dates, ~details,
  "Ph.D.", "University of Statistics", "California", "2020-2024",
  c("Thesis: Statistical Analysis of Data",
    "Published 3 papers in top journals",
    "Received Excellence Award"),
  "M.Sc.", "College of Data", "New York", "2018-2020",
  c("Focus on Machine Learning",
    "GPA: 4.0/4.0")
) %>%
  detailed_entries(
    what = title,
    when = dates,
    with = unit,
    where = loc,
    why = details
  )
Brief Entries

Use brief_entries() for shorter items like publications or certifications:

tribble(
  ~role, ~year, ~inst,
  "Best Paper Award", "2023", "Statistics Conference",
  "R Programming Certificate", "2022", "DataCamp"
) %>%
  brief_entries(
    what = role,
    when = year,
    with = inst
  )
Honor Entries

The new honor_entries() function is perfect for achievements and awards:

tribble(
  ~award, ~year, ~org, ~location,
  "Outstanding Researcher", "2023", "Science Foundation", "National",
  "Teaching Excellence", "2022", "University", "Department"
) %>%
  honor_entries(
    what = award,
    when = year,
    with = org,
    where = location
  )
Skill Entries

Use skill_entries() to showcase your expertise:

tribble(
  ~category, ~details,
  "Programming", "R, Python, SQL, Julia",
  "Statistics", "Regression, Time Series, Machine Learning",
  "Languages", "English (Native), Spanish (Fluent)"
) %>%
  skill_entries(
    type = category,
    details = details
  )

Complete Example

Here’s a minimal working example combining all entry types:

---
title: "Professional Resume"
author: Jane Doe
output: vitae::crisp
position: "Data Scientist"
email: "jane.doe@email.com"
github: "janedoe"
spacing_after_section_title: "-1mm"
headcolor: "00FF00" # green
---

# Education
tribble(
  ~degree, ~uni, ~loc, ~dates, ~details,
  "Ph.D.", "Stats University", "USA", "2020-2024", c("Thesis on Advanced Analytics"),
  "B.S in Biology", "Biology University", "USA", "2016-2020", c("Thesis on Biology")
) %>% 
  detailed_entries(
    what = degree,
    when = dates,
    with = uni,
    where = loc,
    why = details
  )
#> Warning: Detailed entry formatter is not defined for this output format.
#> # A tibble: 2 × 5
#>   what           when      with               where why      
#>   <chr>          <chr>     <chr>              <chr> <list>   
#> 1 Ph.D.          2020-2024 Stats University   USA   <chr [1]>
#> 2 B.S in Biology 2016-2020 Biology University USA   <chr [1]>

Skills 

tribble(
  ~category, ~details,
  "Analysis", "Statistics, Machine Learning, Data Mining",
  "Programming", "R, Python, SQL",
  "Reserch", "Biology, Genetics",
  "Visualization", "Rmarkdown, streamlit, shiny",
  "DevOps", "Github, AWS, GCP, docker, nextflow"
) %>%
  skill_entries(
    type = category,
    details = details
  )
#> Warning: Skill entry formatter is not defined for this output format.
#> # A tibble: 5 × 2
#>   type          details                                  
#>   <chr>         <chr>                                    
#> 1 Analysis      Statistics, Machine Learning, Data Mining
#> 2 Programming   R, Python, SQL                           
#> 3 Reserch       Biology, Genetics                        
#> 4 Visualization Rmarkdown, streamlit, shiny              
#> 5 DevOps        Github, AWS, GCP, docker, nextflow

Honors 

tribble(
  ~award, ~year, ~org, ~loc,
  "Best Paper1", "2023", "Conference4", "International",
  "Best Paper2", "2022", "Conference3", "International",
  "Best Paper3", "2021", "Conference2", "International",
  "Best Paper4", "2020", "Conference1", "International"
) %>%
  honor_entries(
    what = award,
    when = year,
    with = org,
    where = loc
  )
#> Warning: Honor entry formatter is not defined for this output format.
#> # A tibble: 4 × 4
#>   what        when  with        where        
#>   <chr>       <chr> <chr>       <chr>        
#> 1 Best Paper1 2023  Conference4 International
#> 2 Best Paper2 2022  Conference3 International
#> 3 Best Paper3 2021  Conference2 International
#> 4 Best Paper4 2020  Conference1 International

Publications 

tribble(
  ~title, ~year, ~journal,
  "Amazing Research Paper", "2023", "Journal of Data Science",
  "Bioinformatics Paper", "2022", "Journal of Bioinformatics",
  "Genetics Paper","2020","Journal of Genetics"
) %>%
  brief_entries(
    what = title,
    when = year,
    with = journal
  )
#> Warning: Brief entry formatter is not defined for this output format.
#> # A tibble: 3 × 3
#>   what                   when  with                     
#>   <chr>                  <chr> <chr>                    
#> 1 Amazing Research Paper 2023  Journal of Data Science  
#> 2 Bioinformatics Paper   2022  Journal of Bioinformatics
#> 3 Genetics Paper         2020  Journal of Genetics

```

Customization Tips

  1. Section Spacing: Adjust vertical space between sections using spacing_after_section_title in YAML header
  2. Monochrome Output: Set headcolor: "000000" in YAML header
  3. Entry Spacing: Each entry type has built-in spacing optimized for compact layout
  4. Protection: Use .protect = TRUE (default) to handle LaTeX special characters

Common Issues and Solutions

  1. LaTeX Errors: Ensure you have a complete TeX distribution installed
  2. Font Issues: The template uses specific fonts that should be installed with the package
  3. Spacing: Fine-tune using spacing_after_section_title and LaTeX spacing commands if needed

Conclusion

The crisp template provides a professional, compact layout suitable for most resume needs. By combining different entry types (detailed_entries, brief_entries, honor_entries, and skill_entries), you can create a well-structured and comprehensive resume.

Developed by Mitchell O’Hara-Wild, Rob Hyndman.

Site built with pkgdown 2.1.3.
